title.narrative: Plantwise training to improve the agricultural advisory system for integrated pest and disease management in Burundi

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Lancement des cliniques des plantes à Mpanda @BubanzaProvince lundi 16/08/2021
Plant doctor training by trained Burundian Master trainers, 22 - 30 March, 2021

Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value: Not applicable in the reporting period

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please **For TMT+:** Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
During the reporting period,
1. A virtual inception workshop, involving participants from ISABU, NUFFIC, IFDC, AUXFIN, the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherland (EKN), Bujumbura, ICCO, and CABI, was successfully held (22 – 23 October 2020) where project execution partners were updated on the scope of the project including concept, objectives, components, outputs, and project delivery structure. Additionally, discussing with partners, the project work plan was collaboratively developed; 2. Fifteen (15) lead experts/ToTs (mentioned in A.E.3) were successfully trained on a short course (11 – 20 March 2021) on field diagnostics (Plantwise Module 1) and best practice delivery of advice to farmers through plant clinics (Plantwise Module 2). Through the training, the knowledge and skills of those trained (on diagnosis and management of plant health problems) were assessed to have increased by 12%. Amongst those trained, five were female. 3. Twenty-five (25) plant doctors (mentioned in A.S.1) were successfully trained (22 – 30 March 2021) by ToTs, with backstopping by CABI experts, on (i) principles of field diagnosis of plant health problems and providing simplified details/characteristics of pest groups (Plantwise Module 1), (ii) giving good advice to farmers (Plantwise Module 2), and (iii) electronic capture of plant clinic data. Among those trained, three were female. 4. Nine lead experts (selected from among those mentioned in A.E.3) and 15 plant doctors (selected from among those mentioned in A.S.1) were successfully trained (6 – 18 June 2021) on (i) the importance of pest management methods that embrace an array of techniques including use of biological control agents as part of Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and on (ii) diagnostics and management of the invasive fall armyworm

title.narrative: A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: During the reporting period, 9 lead experts (selected from among those mentioned in A.E.3) and 15 plant doctors (selected from among those mentioned in A.S.1) were trained on gender-sensitive advisory service provision. This training offered to individuals from ISABU (4), DPV (5), FABI (1), and BPEAE (15) creates gender awareness and supports adoption, in these institutions, of good practices (including (i) targeting community-based women’s groups for training, and communication about plant clinic services; and (ii) consulting time, and location of plant clinics with men and women community members) that help women access plant health advisory services. Amongst the participants, six were female.

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 03-11-2021: 1. Faculty of Agriculture of the University of Burundi (FABI) was involved in each activity carried out during the reporting period, including having one of its staff members trained as a master trainer for plant doctor modules. In addition, FABI is represented in the National Steering Committee for Plantwise in Burundi. 2. Through the stakeholder analysis carried out in the reporting period, TVETs were identified as being the ideal institutions for integrating plant doctor modules into their curricula. Consequently, in the next reporting period, opportunities will be sought for integrating plant doctor modules into the curricula of TVETs - either directly by engaging the technical colleges, or indirectly by working with organizations (such as INADES and FIDA (IFAD)) that are actively involved in TVET. We very much hope this will be possible but need to see whether INADES and/or IFAD could be open to collaboration and willing to support this integration.
4 (ISABU, Faculty of Agriculture of the University of Burundi (FABI), Ministry of Environment, Agriculture and Livestock (MINEAGRIE)-DPV, AUXFIN)

title.narrative: A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: 12 plant clinics established in 12 districts. The running of the plant clinics will be funded by the EKN. Nevertheless, without the training made possible with this TMT+, the plant clinics couldn’t operate. Therefore we can keep this indicator in the LF

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 03-11-2021: Through a Training of Trainers (ToT) model, lead experts from relevant institutions: Institut des Sciences Agronomiques du Burundi (ISABU) – 6, Direction de la Protection des Végétaux (DPV) – 8, and Faculty of Agriculture of the University of Burundi (FABI) – 1 underwent a training course organized in two modules: Plantwise Module 1, focusing on symptom-based field diagnosis of pests, and Plantwise Module 2, focusing on the practical delivery of integrated pest management (IPM)-based advice to farmers. As a result of participating in the training course, the lead experts (master trainers) will be able to train agricultural advisors (those intending to serve as plant doctors) on visual pest diagnosis and on giving good advice to farmers through plant clinics.

title.narrative: A.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques

comment.narrative: 08-11-2021: Through mentorship by CABI, the lead experts (mentioned in A.E.3) trained the first cohort of plant doctors (agricultural advisors to operate plant clinics) on visual pest diagnosis and on giving good advice to farmers through plant clinics. The plant doctors, numbering 25 (3 female), are extension staff employed by the Bureau Provinciale de L’Environnement, de l’Agriculture et de l’Elevage (BPEAE)
500 male and female farmers reached with knowledge directly through plant clinics 100 user visits from Burundi to the Plantwise Knowledge bank

title.narrative: I.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques
FNS.2 Promote agricultural growth
FNS.2.1. Number of family farms (sub-sector, male/female, age: % < 35) with increased productivity and/or income

comment.narrative: 02-11-2021: Though not applicable in the reporting period, we are on track to reach our long-term indicator being the reach of 2000 farmers, which will have increased their productivity and income. Once pilot plant clinics start operating (next reporting period), the project will start reaching farmers. It is expected, with the complementary funding from the EKN Bujumbura until the end of 2023 (that will see the implementation of the entire Plantwise approach in Burundi), and based on experience from elsewhere where Plantwise was implemented, in the long-term, the project will positively impact productivity and income of many more family farms.

32 plant doctors trained so far. Assuming each plant doctor reaches 150 farmers per year then farmers reached would be-32\*150 reaching a total of 4800 farmers. 960 is 20% of the total reach The total reach will be achieved through continued work funded by EKN

title.narrative: II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.1. Number of MoUs or other types of formal collaboration agreements exist 1, 3, 5 years after end of project
II.P.5. Number of academic staff of partner country still cooperates with academic staff of other education organisation(s)

comment.narrative: After clarification of the indicators, partners are making an estimation of the target. The staff that is considered here is broader than 'academic'.

title.narrative: II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods

comment.narrative: CABI itself: Through the NUFFIC training, CABI has been able to test its assumption that within a relatively short timeframe (and even under global pandemic conditions) it is able to build in-country capacity through tailored training while fitting with FNS activities

comment.narrative: 50-75% reported positive effects in terms of increased job satisfaction and feeling more effective in supporting smallholder farmers become more productive.
